trans-unit.source: Connect to on-premises SQL Server from an API app in Azure App Service using Hybrid Connections
trans-unit.target: Connect to on-premises SQL Server from an API app in Azure App Service using Hybrid Connections

trans-unit.source: Create an API app on Microsoft Azure and connect it to an on-premises SQL Server database
trans-unit.target: Create an API app on Microsoft Azure and connect it to an on-premises SQL Server database

trans-unit.source: Hybrid Connections can connect <linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title> API apps to on-premises resources that use a static TCP port.
trans-unit.target: Hybrid Connections can connect <linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title> API apps to on-premises resources that use a static TCP port.

trans-unit.source: Supported resources include Microsoft SQL Server, MySQL, HTTP Web APIs, Mobile Services, and most custom Web Services.
trans-unit.target: Supported resources include Microsoft SQL Server, MySQL, HTTP Web APIs, Mobile Services, and most custom Web Services.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will learn how to create an App Service API app in the <linkText>Azure preview</linkText><title></title> that connects to a local on-premises SQL Server database using the new Hybrid Connection feature.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will learn how to create an App Service API app in the <linkText>Azure preview</linkText><title></title> that connects to a local on-premises SQL Server database using the new Hybrid Connection feature.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial assumes no prior experience using Azure or SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial assumes no prior experience using Azure or SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you'll need the following products.
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you'll need the following products.

trans-unit.source: All are available in free versions, so you can start developing Azure solutions entirely for free.
trans-unit.target: All are available in free versions, so you can start developing Azure solutions entirely for free.

trans-unit.source: Azure subscription - For a free subscription, see Azure Free Trial.
trans-unit.target: Azure subscription - For a free subscription, see Azure Free Trial.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio - To download a free trial version of Visual Studio 2013 or Visual Studio 2015, see Visual Studio Downloads.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio - To download a free trial version of Visual Studio 2013 or Visual Studio 2015, see Visual Studio Downloads.

trans-unit.source: Install one of these before continuing.
trans-unit.target: Install one of these before continuing.

trans-unit.source: (The screen shots in this tutorial were taken using Visual Studio 2013)
trans-unit.target: (The screen shots in this tutorial were taken using Visual Studio 2013)

trans-unit.source: SQL Server 2014 Express with Tools - download Microsoft SQL Server Express for free at the Microsoft Web Platform Database page.
trans-unit.target: SQL Server 2014 Express with Tools - download Microsoft SQL Server Express for free at the Microsoft Web Platform Database page.

trans-unit.source: Later in this tutorial, you'll see how to <linkText>install SQL Server</linkText><title></title> to ensure that it is properly configured.
trans-unit.target: Later in this tutorial, you'll see how to <linkText>install SQL Server</linkText><title></title> to ensure that it is properly configured.

trans-unit.source: SQL Server Management Studio Express - This is included with the SQL Server 2014 Express with Tools download mentioned above, but if you need to install it separately, you can download and install it from the SQL Server Express download page.
trans-unit.target: SQL Server Management Studio Express - This is included with the SQL Server 2014 Express with Tools download mentioned above, but if you need to install it separately, you can download and install it from the SQL Server Express download page.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial assumes that you have an Azure subscription, that you have installed Visual Studio 2013, and that you have installed or enabled .NET Framework 3.5.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial assumes that you have an Azure subscription, that you have installed Visual Studio 2013, and that you have installed or enabled .NET Framework 3.5.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial shows you how to install SQL Server 2014 Express in a configuration that works well with the Azure Hybrid Connections feature (a default instance with a static TCP port).
trans-unit.target: The tutorial shows you how to install SQL Server 2014 Express in a configuration that works well with the Azure Hybrid Connections feature (a default instance with a static TCP port).

trans-unit.source: Before starting the tutorial, download (but, do not install) SQL Server 2014 Express with Tools from the location mentioned above if you do not have SQL Server installed.
trans-unit.target: Before starting the tutorial, download (but, do not install) SQL Server 2014 Express with Tools from the location mentioned above if you do not have SQL Server installed.

trans-unit.source: To use an on-premises SQL Server or SQL Server Express database with a hybrid connection, TCP/IP needs to be enabled on a static port.
trans-unit.target: To use an on-premises SQL Server or SQL Server Express database with a hybrid connection, TCP/IP needs to be enabled on a static port.

trans-unit.source: Default instances on SQL Server use static port 1433, whereas named instances do not.
trans-unit.target: Default instances on SQL Server use static port 1433, whereas named instances do not.

trans-unit.source: The computer on which you install the on-premises Hybrid Connection Manager agent:
trans-unit.target: The computer on which you install the on-premises Hybrid Connection Manager agent:

trans-unit.source: Must have outbound connectivity to Azure over:
trans-unit.target: Must have outbound connectivity to Azure over:

trans-unit.source: Port
trans-unit.target: Port

trans-unit.source: Why
trans-unit.target: Why

trans-unit.source: Required
trans-unit.target: Required

trans-unit.source: for HTTP port for certificate validation and optionally for data connectivity.
trans-unit.target: for HTTP port for certificate validation and optionally for data connectivity.

trans-unit.source: Optional
trans-unit.target: Optional

trans-unit.source: for data connectivity. If outbound connectivity to 443 is unavailable, TCP port 80 is used.
trans-unit.target: for data connectivity. If outbound connectivity to 443 is unavailable, TCP port 80 is used.

trans-unit.source: Recommended
trans-unit.target: Recommended

trans-unit.source: but Optional for data connectivity. Note this mode usually yields higher throughput. If outbound connectivity to these ports is unavailable, TCP port 443 is used.
trans-unit.target: but Optional for data connectivity. Note this mode usually yields higher throughput. If outbound connectivity to these ports is unavailable, TCP port 443 is used.

trans-unit.source: Must be able to reach the hostname:portnumber of your on-premises resource.
trans-unit.target: Must be able to reach the hostname:portnumber of your on-premises resource.

trans-unit.source: The steps in this article assume that you are using the browser from the computer that will host the on-premises hybrid connection agent.
trans-unit.target: The steps in this article assume that you are using the browser from the computer that will host the on-premises hybrid connection agent.

trans-unit.source: If you already have SQL Server installed in a configuration and in an environment that meets the conditions described above, you can skip ahead and start with <linkText>Create a SQL Server database on-premises</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you already have SQL Server installed in a configuration and in an environment that meets the conditions described above, you can skip ahead and start with <linkText>Create a SQL Server database on-premises</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This section shows you how to install SQL Server Express, enable TCP/IP, and create a database so that your API app will work with the <linkText>Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This section shows you how to install SQL Server Express, enable TCP/IP, and create a database so that your API app will work with the <linkText>Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To install SQL Server Express, download the either SQLEXPRWT_x64_ENU.exe (64-bit version) or SQLEXPR_x86_ENU.exe (32-bit version) file and extract it to the desired folder.
trans-unit.target: To install SQL Server Express, download the either SQLEXPRWT_x64_ENU.exe (64-bit version) or SQLEXPR_x86_ENU.exe (32-bit version) file and extract it to the desired folder.

trans-unit.source: Once you have extracted the SQL Server Express installation files, run setup.exe.
trans-unit.target: Once you have extracted the SQL Server Express installation files, run setup.exe.

trans-unit.source: When the SQL Server Installation Center displays, choose New SQL Server stand-alone installation or add features to an existing installation.
trans-unit.target: When the SQL Server Installation Center displays, choose New SQL Server stand-alone installation or add features to an existing installation.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SQL Server Installation Center</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SQL Server Installation Center</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions, accepting the default choices and settings, until you get to the Instance Configuration page.
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions, accepting the default choices and settings, until you get to the Instance Configuration page.

trans-unit.source: On the Instance Configuration page, choose Default instance, and click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Instance Configuration page, choose Default instance, and click Next.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Instance Configuration</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Instance Configuration</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The default instance of SQL Server listens for requests from SQL Server clients on static port 1433, which is what the Hybrid Connections feature requires.
trans-unit.target: The default instance of SQL Server listens for requests from SQL Server clients on static port 1433, which is what the Hybrid Connections feature requires.

trans-unit.source: Named instances use dynamic ports and UDP, which are not supported by Hybrid Connections.
trans-unit.target: Named instances use dynamic ports and UDP, which are not supported by Hybrid Connections.

trans-unit.source: Accept the defaults on the Server Configuration page, and click Next.
trans-unit.target: Accept the defaults on the Server Configuration page, and click Next.

trans-unit.source: On the Database Engine Configuration page, under Authentication Mode, choose Mixed Mode (SQL Server authentication and Windows authentication), and provide a password.
trans-unit.target: On the Database Engine Configuration page, under Authentication Mode, choose Mixed Mode (SQL Server authentication and Windows authentication), and provide a password.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Database Engine Configuration</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Database Engine Configuration</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will be using SQL Server authentication.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will be using SQL Server authentication.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to remember the password that you provide, because you will need it later.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to remember the password that you provide, because you will need it later.

trans-unit.source: Step through the rest of the wizard - accepting the defaults as you go - to complete the installation.
trans-unit.target: Step through the rest of the wizard - accepting the defaults as you go - to complete the installation.

trans-unit.source: Close the SQL Server Installation Center dialog.
trans-unit.target: Close the SQL Server Installation Center dialog.

trans-unit.source: To enable TCP/IP, you will use SQL Server Configuration Manager, which was installed when you installed SQL Server Express.
trans-unit.target: To enable TCP/IP, you will use SQL Server Configuration Manager, which was installed when you installed SQL Server Express.

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps in <linkText>Enable TCP/IP Network Protocol for SQL Server</linkText><title></title> before continuing.
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps in <linkText>Enable TCP/IP Network Protocol for SQL Server</linkText><title></title> before continuing.

trans-unit.source: In SQL Server Management Studio, connect to the SQL Server you just installed.
trans-unit.target: In SQL Server Management Studio, connect to the SQL Server you just installed.

trans-unit.source: For Server type, choose Database Engine.
trans-unit.target: For Server type, choose Database Engine.

trans-unit.source: For Server name, you can use localhost or the name of the computer that you are using.
trans-unit.target: For Server name, you can use localhost or the name of the computer that you are using.

trans-unit.source: Choose SQL Server authentication, and then log in with the sa user name, and the password that you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: Choose SQL Server authentication, and then log in with the sa user name, and the password that you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Connect to Server</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Connect to Server</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If the Connect to Server dialog does not appear automatically, navigate to Object Explorer in the left pane, click Connect, and then click Database Engine.
trans-unit.target: If the Connect to Server dialog does not appear automatically, navigate to Object Explorer in the left pane, click Connect, and then click Database Engine.

trans-unit.source: To create a new database by using SQL Server Management Studio, right-click Databases in Object Explorer, and then click New Database.
trans-unit.target: To create a new database by using SQL Server Management Studio, right-click Databases in Object Explorer, and then click New Database.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create new database menu</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create new database menu</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the New Database dialog, enter LocalDatabase for the database name, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: In the New Database dialog, enter LocalDatabase for the database name, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Creating new database</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Creating new database</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the SQL Server Management Studio Object Explorer, expand the LocalDatabase entry.
trans-unit.target: In the SQL Server Management Studio Object Explorer, expand the LocalDatabase entry.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Database expanded</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Database expanded</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Right-click Tables and select the Table... option from the context menu.
trans-unit.target: Right-click Tables and select the Table... option from the context menu.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New table menu</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New table menu</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When the table designer grid appears, enter the column information as shown in the following figure.
trans-unit.target: When the table designer grid appears, enter the column information as shown in the following figure.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New table columns</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New table columns</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Press <Ctrl>S to save the new table's definition.
trans-unit.target: Press <Ctrl>S to save the new table's definition.

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to enter a table name.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to enter a table name.

trans-unit.source: Enter Speakers and press OK.
trans-unit.target: Enter Speakers and press OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Save new table</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Save new table</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In Object Explorer, right-click the newly created Speakers table, and select Edit top 200 rows from the context menu.
trans-unit.target: In Object Explorer, right-click the newly created Speakers table, and select Edit top 200 rows from the context menu.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Edit top 200 rows</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Edit top 200 rows</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When the grid appears to enter/modify the table data, enter some test data as shown in the following figure.
trans-unit.target: When the grid appears to enter/modify the table data, enter some test data as shown in the following figure.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Test data</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Test data</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This section walks you through creating the demo API app.
trans-unit.target: This section walks you through creating the demo API app.

trans-unit.source: Open Visual Studio 2013 and select File > New > Project.
trans-unit.target: Open Visual Studio 2013 and select File > New > Project.

trans-unit.source: Select the Visual C# > Web > ASP.NET Web Application template, clear the Add application insights to project option, name the project SpeakersList, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Select the Visual C# > Web > ASP.NET Web Application template, clear the Add application insights to project option, name the project SpeakersList, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: On the New ASP.NET Project dialog, select the Azure API App project template and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: On the New ASP.NET Project dialog, select the Azure API App project template and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: In the Solution Explorer, right-click the Models folder, and then select the Add > Class... context menu option.
trans-unit.target: In the Solution Explorer, right-click the Models folder, and then select the Add > Class... context menu option.

trans-unit.source: Name the new file Speaker.cs, and then click Add.
trans-unit.target: Name the new file Speaker.cs, and then click Add.

trans-unit.source: Replace the entire contents of the Speaker.cs file with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Replace the entire contents of the Speaker.cs file with the following code.

trans-unit.source: In the Solution Explorer, right-click the Controllers folder, and then select the Add > Controller... context menu option.
trans-unit.target: In the Solution Explorer, right-click the Controllers folder, and then select the Add > Controller... context menu option.

trans-unit.source: In the Add Scaffold dialog, select the Web API 2 Controller - Empty option and click Add.
trans-unit.target: In the Add Scaffold dialog, select the Web API 2 Controller - Empty option and click Add.

trans-unit.source: Name the controller SpeakersController and click Add.
trans-unit.target: Name the controller SpeakersController and click Add.

trans-unit.source: Replace the code in the SpeakersController.cs file with the code below.
trans-unit.target: Replace the code in the SpeakersController.cs file with the code below.

trans-unit.source: Make sure to specify your own values for the <serverName> and <password> placeholders in the connectionString.
trans-unit.target: Make sure to specify your own values for the <serverName> and <password> placeholders in the connectionString.

trans-unit.source: The <serverName> value is the machine name on which the SQL Server is located, and the <password> value is the one you set when you installed and configured SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: The <serverName> value is the machine name on which the SQL Server is located, and the <password> value is the one you set when you installed and configured SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: The following code snippet includes password information.
trans-unit.target: The following code snippet includes password information.

trans-unit.source: This was done to keep the demo simple.
trans-unit.target: This was done to keep the demo simple.

trans-unit.source: In a real-world production environment, you should not store your credentials in code.
trans-unit.target: In a real-world production environment, you should not store your credentials in code.

trans-unit.source: Instead, refer to the <linkText>best practices for deploying passwords (and other sensitive data) to ASP.NET and Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Instead, refer to the <linkText>best practices for deploying passwords (and other sensitive data) to ASP.NET and Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Enabling the Swagger UI will allow you to easily test your API app without having to write client code to call it.
trans-unit.target: Enabling the Swagger UI will allow you to easily test your API app without having to write client code to call it.

trans-unit.source: Open the App_Start/SwaggerConfig.cs file, and search for EnableSwaggerUI:
trans-unit.target: Open the App_Start/SwaggerConfig.cs file, and search for EnableSwaggerUI:

trans-unit.source: Uncomment the following lines of code:
trans-unit.target: Uncomment the following lines of code:

trans-unit.source: When you're done, verify that the file looks like the following image.
trans-unit.target: When you're done, verify that the file looks like the following image.

trans-unit.source: To view the API test page, run the app locally via <Ctrl>F5.
trans-unit.target: To view the API test page, run the app locally via <Ctrl>F5.

trans-unit.source: You should see an error similar to the following image.
trans-unit.target: You should see an error similar to the following image.

trans-unit.source: In your browser's address bar, add /swagger to the end of the URL, and then click <Enter>.
trans-unit.target: In your browser's address bar, add /swagger to the end of the URL, and then click <Enter>.

trans-unit.source: This will display the Swagger UI you enabled in the previous section.
trans-unit.target: This will display the Swagger UI you enabled in the previous section.

trans-unit.source: Click the Speakers section to expand it.
trans-unit.target: Click the Speakers section to expand it.

trans-unit.source: Click GET /api/speakers to expand that section.
trans-unit.target: Click GET /api/speakers to expand that section.

trans-unit.source: Click Try it out! to view the data you entered into the database earlier.
trans-unit.target: Click Try it out! to view the data you entered into the database earlier.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've tested the app locally, it's time to deploy the app to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've tested the app locally, it's time to deploy the app to Azure.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project (not the solution) and click Publish....
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project (not the solution) and click Publish....

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Project publish menu option</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Project publish menu option</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the Profile tab and click Microsoft Azure API Apps (Preview).
trans-unit.target: Click the Profile tab and click Microsoft Azure API Apps (Preview).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Project publish menu option</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Project publish menu option</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click New to provision a new API app in your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Click New to provision a new API app in your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Select Existing API Services dialog</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Select Existing API Services dialog</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Create an API App dialog, enter the following:
trans-unit.target: In the Create an API App dialog, enter the following:

trans-unit.source: Under API App Name, enter a name for the app.
trans-unit.target: Under API App Name, enter a name for the app.

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple Azure subscriptions, select the one you want to use.
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple Azure subscriptions, select the one you want to use.

trans-unit.source: Under App Service Plan, select from your existing App Service plans, or select Create new App Service plan and enter the name of a new plan.
trans-unit.target: Under App Service Plan, select from your existing App Service plans, or select Create new App Service plan and enter the name of a new plan.

trans-unit.source: Under Resource Group, select from your existing resource groups, or select Create new resource group and enter a name.
trans-unit.target: Under Resource Group, select from your existing resource groups, or select Create new resource group and enter a name.

trans-unit.source: The name must be unique; consider using the app name as a prefix and appending some personal information such as your Microsoft ID (without the @ sign).
trans-unit.target: The name must be unique; consider using the app name as a prefix and appending some personal information such as your Microsoft ID (without the @ sign).

trans-unit.source: Under Access Level, select Available to Anyone.
trans-unit.target: Under Access Level, select Available to Anyone.

trans-unit.source: This option will make your API completely public, which is fine for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: This option will make your API completely public, which is fine for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: You can restrict access later through the <linkText>Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can restrict access later through the <linkText>Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Select a region.
trans-unit.target: Select a region.

trans-unit.source: Click OK to create the API app in your subscription.
trans-unit.target: Click OK to create the API app in your subscription.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Configure Microsoft Azure Web App dialog</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Configure Microsoft Azure Web App dialog</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The process can take a few minutes, so Visual Studio shows a dialog notifying you that the process has initiated.
trans-unit.target: The process can take a few minutes, so Visual Studio shows a dialog notifying you that the process has initiated.

trans-unit.source: Click OK to the confirmation dialog.
trans-unit.target: Click OK to the confirmation dialog.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>API Service Creation Started confirmation message</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>API Service Creation Started confirmation message</linkText>

trans-unit.source: While the provisioning process is creating the resource group and API app in your Azure subscription, Visual Studio shows the progress in the Azure App Service Activity window.
trans-unit.target: While the provisioning process is creating the resource group and API app in your Azure subscription, Visual Studio shows the progress in the Azure App Service Activity window.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Status notification via the Azure App Service Activity window</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Status notification via the Azure App Service Activity window</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Once the API App is provisioned, right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select Publish to re-open the publish dialog.
trans-unit.target: Once the API App is provisioned, right-click the project in Solution Explorer and select Publish to re-open the publish dialog.

trans-unit.source: The publish profile created in the previous step should be pre-selected.
trans-unit.target: The publish profile created in the previous step should be pre-selected.

trans-unit.source: Click Publish to begin the deployment process.
trans-unit.target: Click Publish to begin the deployment process.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Deploying the API App</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Deploying the API App</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Azure App Service Activity window shows the deployment progress, and will indicate when the publish process has completed.
trans-unit.target: The Azure App Service Activity window shows the deployment progress, and will indicate when the publish process has completed.

trans-unit.source: In your browser, navigate to the <linkText>Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: In your browser, navigate to the <linkText>Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click the Browse All option on the left.
trans-unit.target: Click the Browse All option on the left.

trans-unit.source: In the Browse blade, select API Apps.
trans-unit.target: In the Browse blade, select API Apps.

trans-unit.source: In the API Apps blade, locate your API app and click it.
trans-unit.target: In the API Apps blade, locate your API app and click it.

trans-unit.source: In your APII app's blade, click the value under API app host.
trans-unit.target: In your APII app's blade, click the value under API app host.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>API App blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>API App blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When the API App Host blade appears, scroll down to the Networking section and click Hybrid connections.
trans-unit.target: When the API App Host blade appears, scroll down to the Networking section and click Hybrid connections.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Hybrid connections</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Hybrid connections</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the Hybrid connections blade, click Add > New hybrid connection.
trans-unit.target: On the Hybrid connections blade, click Add > New hybrid connection.

trans-unit.source: On the Create hybrid connection blade:
trans-unit.target: On the Create hybrid connection blade:

trans-unit.source: For Name, provide a name for the connection.
trans-unit.target: For Name, provide a name for the connection.

trans-unit.source: For Hostname, enter the computer name of your SQL Server host computer.
trans-unit.target: For Hostname, enter the computer name of your SQL Server host computer.

trans-unit.source: For Port, enter 1433 (the default port for SQL Server).
trans-unit.target: For Port, enter 1433 (the default port for SQL Server).

trans-unit.source: Click Biz Talk Service and enter a name for the BizTalk service.
trans-unit.target: Click Biz Talk Service and enter a name for the BizTalk service.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a hybrid connection</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a hybrid connection</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click OK twice.
trans-unit.target: Click OK twice.

trans-unit.source: When the process completes, the Notifications area will flash a green SUCCESS and the Hybrid connections blade will show the new hybrid connection with the status as Not connected.
trans-unit.target: When the process completes, the Notifications area will flash a green SUCCESS and the Hybrid connections blade will show the new hybrid connection with the status as Not connected.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Hybrid connection created</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Hybrid connection created</linkText>

trans-unit.source: At this point, you have completed an important part of the cloud hybrid connection infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you have completed an important part of the cloud hybrid connection infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: Next, you will create a corresponding on-premises piece.
trans-unit.target: Next, you will create a corresponding on-premises piece.

trans-unit.source: Now that the hybrid connection infrastructure is complete, it's time to test the application.
trans-unit.target: Now that the hybrid connection infrastructure is complete, it's time to test the application.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure preview portal, return to the API app host blade, and click the value under URL.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure preview portal, return to the API app host blade, and click the value under URL.

trans-unit.source: Once the API app's host page is displayed in your browser, append /swagger to the URL in your browser's address bar and click <Enter>.
trans-unit.target: Once the API app's host page is displayed in your browser, append /swagger to the URL in your browser's address bar and click <Enter>.

trans-unit.source: Click the Speakers section to expand it.
trans-unit.target: Click the Speakers section to expand it.

trans-unit.source: Click GET /api/speakers to expand that section.
trans-unit.target: Click GET /api/speakers to expand that section.

trans-unit.source: Click Try it out! to view the data you entered into the database earlier.
trans-unit.target: Click Try it out! to view the data you entered into the database earlier.

trans-unit.source: Congratulations! You have created an API app that runs on Azure and uses a hybrid connection to connect to a local on-premises SQL Server database.
trans-unit.target: Congratulations! You have created an API app that runs on Azure and uses a hybrid connection to connect to a local on-premises SQL Server database.
